info.name: Watchman Java API
info.description:
# Watchman Java API

**Sanctions Screening Service** - Screen individuals and businesses against global sanctions lists (OFAC, EU, UK, UN).

## üöÄ Quick Start

1. Set `baseUrl` variable to your environment
2. Use `/v2/search` for single entity screening
3. Use `/v2/search/batch` for bulk screening (up to 1000 items)

## üìö Key Features

- **Single Entity Search**: Real-time screening with fuzzy matching
- **Batch Screening**: Process up to 1000 entities in one request
- **Score Tracing**: Debug scoring with `trace=true` for detailed breakdowns
- **Flexible Filtering**: Filter by source list, entity type, or custom thresholds
- **High Performance**: Parallel processing with sub-second response times

## üéØ Common Use Cases

**KYC Onboarding**: Screen new customers during registration
```
GET /v2/search?name=John%20Doe&minMatch=0.85
```

**Transaction Monitoring**: Batch screen payment recipients
```
POST /v2/search/batch
{ "items": [{"id": "txn-1", "name": "Recipient Name"}], "minMatch": 0.9 }
```

**Score Tuning**: Use trace mode to optimize thresholds
```
GET /v2/search?name=Test&trace=true
```

## üåç Data Sources

- **OFAC SDN**: US Treasury sanctions list (~12,500 entities)
- **US CSL**: Consolidated Screening List (~8,000 entities)
- **EU CSL**: European Union sanctions (~5,000 entities)
- **UK CSL**: UK sanctions list (~3,000 entities)

## ‚öôÔ∏è Configuration

**Base URLs**:
- Local Development: `http://localhost:8084`
- Production (Fly.io): `https://watchman-java.fly.dev`

**Default Parameters**:
- `minMatch`: 0.85 (85% similarity threshold)
- `limit`: 10 results per query

## üìñ Documentation

Each folder contains detailed endpoint documentation with:
- Parameter descriptions and examples
- Response schemas with sample data
- Best practices and performance tips
- Common error scenarios

## üîç Score Tracing

Enable detailed scoring breakdowns for debugging:
- **Single Search**: Add `?trace=true` query parameter
- **Batch Search**: Add `"trace": true` to request body

Trace output includes:
- Component scores (name, address, DOB, ID)
- Normalization steps
- Candidate selection process
- Final score calculation

item.name: Health & Info
item.description:
## Health & System Information

Monitor service health and get information about loaded sanctions data.

### Endpoints

- **GET /health** - Service health check
- **GET /v2/listinfo** - Available sanctions lists and counts

### Use Cases

‚úÖ **Readiness Checks**: Verify service is ready before screening
‚úÖ **Monitoring**: Set up health check alerts
‚úÖ **Data Validation**: Confirm expected entity counts are loaded
‚úÖ **Debugging**: Check which lists are available for filtering

### Best Practices

- Poll `/health` endpoint for uptime monitoring
- Check `/listinfo` after data refresh to verify counts
- Use list names from `/listinfo` for source filtering in searches

request.description: Check if the service is healthy and running
Get information about available sanctions lists

item.name: Search
item.description:
## Single Entity Search

Screen individual names against global sanctions lists with real-time fuzzy matching.

### Endpoint

```
GET /v2/search?name={query}&minMatch={threshold}&limit={max_results}
```

### Key Parameters

| Parameter | Type | Default | Description |
|-----------|------|---------|-------------|
| `name` | string | required | Name to screen (person or business) |
| `minMatch` | float | 0.85 | Score threshold (0.0-1.0) |
| `limit` | int | 10 | Maximum results to return |
| `source` | string | all | Filter by list (OFAC_SDN, US_CSL, EU_CSL, UK_CSL) |
| `type` | string | all | Filter by type (PERSON, BUSINESS, VESSEL, AIRCRAFT) |
| `trace` | boolean | false | Enable detailed score breakdown |

### Response Structure

```json
{
  "entities": [
    {
      "id": "12345",
      "name": "JOHN DOE",
      "type": "PERSON",
      "source": "OFAC_SDN",
      "score": 0.95,
      "altNames": [...],
      "programs": ["SDGT"],
      "breakdown": null  // populated when trace=true
    }
  ],
  "totalResults": 1,
  "requestID": "req-123",
  "debug": null  // populated when trace=true
}
```

### Performance

- **Average Response Time**: < 50ms
- **P99 Response Time**: < 200ms
- **Concurrent Requests**: 100+ per second

### Scoring Guidelines

| Threshold | Use Case | False Positive Rate |
|-----------|----------|-------------------|
| 0.95+ | High confidence matches only | Very Low |
| 0.85-0.94 | Standard screening (recommended) | Low |
| 0.70-0.84 | Fuzzy matching for variants | Medium |
| < 0.70 | Not recommended | High |

### Best Practices

‚úÖ **Start with 0.85**: Good balance of accuracy and coverage
‚úÖ **Use trace mode**: Debug unexpected scores or missing matches
‚úÖ **Filter by source**: Reduce false positives for specific jurisdictions
‚úÖ **Handle high scores first**: Review 0.95+ matches as highest priority
‚úÖ **Log request IDs**: Include in audit trails for compliance

### Common Patterns

**1. KYC Screening**
```
/v2/search?name=Customer%20Name&minMatch=0.85&limit=5
```

**2. Vendor Due Diligence**
```
/v2/search?name=Vendor%20Corp&type=BUSINESS&minMatch=0.90
```

**3. OFAC-Only Check**
```
/v2/search?name=Test%20Entity&source=OFAC_SDN&minMatch=0.85
```

**4. Debug Low Scores**
```
/v2/search?name=John%20Doe&trace=true&minMatch=0.70
```

request.description:
## Basic Name Search

Screen a name against all sanctions lists using fuzzy matching.

### When to Use
- ‚úÖ KYC customer onboarding
- ‚úÖ Payment beneficiary screening  
- ‚úÖ Vendor due diligence
- ‚úÖ Employee background checks

### Query Parameters

- **name** (required): Name to screen
  - Can be person or business name
  - Case-insensitive
  - Handles name variations automatically

- **limit** (optional, default: 10): Max results
  - Range: 1-100
  - Higher values = more candidates but slower response
  - Tip: Start with 10, increase if missing matches

- **minMatch** (optional, default: 0.85): Score threshold
  - Range: 0.0-1.0
  - 0.85 = 85% similarity
  - Lower values = more matches but more false positives

### Response

**entities[]**: Array of matches
- `id`: Unique entity identifier
- `name`: Official name on sanctions list
- `score`: Match confidence (0.0-1.0)
- `type`: PERSON, BUSINESS, VESSEL, or AIRCRAFT
- `source`: Which list (OFAC_SDN, EU_CSL, etc.)
- `altNames`: Known aliases and variations
- `programs`: Sanctions programs (e.g., SDGT, IRAN)

### Examples

**Person**:
```
/v2/search?name=John%20Doe&limit=10
```

**Business**:
```
/v2/search?name=Acme%20Corporation&limit=10
```

**Low confidence check**:
```
/v2/search?name=Mohammad&minMatch=0.70&limit=50
```

### Tips

üí° **Review scores carefully**: 0.95+ are strong matches, 0.85-0.94 need review
üí° **Check altNames**: Shows why the match was found
üí° **Log requestID**: Include in compliance audit logs

query.description: Filter by source list (OFAC_SDN, US_CSL, EU_CSL, UK_CSL)

response.name: Search Results with Trace

request.description:
## POST Search - Minimal Request

Basic POST search with only a name query. Uses all default configurations.

### When to Use POST vs GET

**Use POST** when:
- üîß Testing custom config overrides (similarity, scoring, search params)
- üß™ Model validation and "what-if" scenarios
- üìä Admin/testing interface for tuning parameters
- üîç Always get trace data (enabled by default for POST)

**Use GET** for:
- ‚úÖ Production screening with standard config
- ‚úÖ Simple name queries
- ‚úÖ RESTful read operations

### Request Body

```json
{
  "query": {
    "name": "Juan Garcia",           // Required
    "addresses": ["123 Main St"],   // Optional
    "govIds": ["ABC123"],           // Optional
    "dateOfBirth": "1990-01-15",    // Optional
    "source": "OFAC_SDN",           // Optional filter
    "type": "PERSON"                // Optional filter
  },
  "config": {                        // Optional overrides
    "similarity": { ... },
    "scoring": { ... },
    "search": { ... }
  },
  "trace": true                      // Optional, defaults to true
}
```

### Default Behavior

- Uses default SimilarityConfig (from application config)
- Uses default ScoringConfig (from application config)
- Uses default search params (minMatch=0.88, limit=10)
- Trace is enabled by default (unlike GET)
- Config metadata included in trace for visibility

### Trace Output

POST responses include:
- Score breakdowns for all matches
- Applied config values in metadata
- Normalization and scoring events
- Perfect for debugging and tuning

response.name: Success with Defaults

request.description:
## POST Search - Similarity Config Override

Test different similarity algorithm parameters to tune fuzzy matching behavior.

### Similarity Parameters

**jaroWinklerBoostThreshold** (default: 0.7)
- Range: 0.0-1.0
- Higher = boost only very similar strings
- Lower = boost more aggressively
- Example: 0.8 means boost prefix matches scoring 80%+

**jaroWinklerPrefixSize** (default: 4)
- Range: 1-10
- Number of prefix characters to favor
- Higher = longer prefix matches get bigger boost
- Example: 5 favors "Mohammad" vs "Moham"

**phoneticFilteringDisabled** (default: false)
- true = disable phonetic matching (Soundex/Metaphone)
- false = use phonetic matching for name variations
- Example: Disable to test pure string matching

**lengthDifferenceCutoffFactor** (default: 3.0)
- Reject candidates with length ratio > factor
- Example: 2.0 rejects "Jo" vs "Jonathan" (ratio 5.5)

**lengthDifferencePenaltyWeight** (default: 0.15)
- Penalty for length mismatch (0.0-1.0)
- Higher = penalize length differences more

**differentLetterPenaltyWeight** (default: 0.1)
- Penalty for different letters (0.0-1.0)
- Higher = penalize character differences more

**unmatchedIndexTokenWeight** (default: 1.0)
- Weight for unmatched tokens in index name
- Lower = reduce penalty for extra words in candidate

**exactMatchFavoritism** (default: 0.05)
- Bonus for exact token matches (0.0-1.0)
- Higher = favor exact word matches more

**keepStopwords** (default: false)
- true = keep stopwords like "the", "and", "of"
- false = remove stopwords during normalization

**logStopwordDebugging** (default: false)
- true = log stopword removal in trace
- false = no stopword debug logging

### Use Cases

- **Testing phonetic impact**: Disable phonetic filtering
- **Tuning prefix sensitivity**: Adjust boost threshold/size
- **Length mismatch tolerance**: Modify cutoff/penalty
- **Exact match preference**: Increase favoritism weight

## POST Search - Scoring Config Override

Adjust component weights and enable/disable scoring features to test different scoring strategies.

### Scoring Weights

**nameWeight** (default: 100.0)
- Weight for primary name match
- Higher = prioritize name matching more
- Example: 50.0 reduces name importance

**addressWeight** (default: 80.0)
- Weight for address match
- Higher = prioritize address matching more
- Example: 120.0 makes address more important than default

**criticalIdWeight** (default: 200.0)
- Weight for critical IDs (passport, SSN, etc.)
- Very high by default (strong signal)

**supportingInfoWeight** (default: 60.0)
- Weight for supporting info (contact, crypto addresses)

### Feature Toggles

**nameEnabled** (default: true)
- Include primary name in scoring

**altNamesEnabled** (default: true)
- Include alternate names in scoring

**governmentIdEnabled** (default: true)
- Include government IDs in scoring

**cryptoEnabled** (default: true)
- Include crypto addresses in scoring

**contactEnabled** (default: true)
- Include contact info in scoring

**addressEnabled** (default: true)
- Include addresses in scoring
- Example: false to test name-only scoring

**dateEnabled** (default: true)
- Include date of birth in scoring
- Example: false to ignore DOB mismatches

### Use Cases

- **Address-focused screening**: Increase addressWeight, decrease nameWeight
- **Name-only validation**: Disable all other features
- **DOB testing**: Toggle dateEnabled to see impact
- **Component isolation**: Enable one feature at a time for debugging

response.name: Success with Custom Scoring

request.description:
## POST Search - Search Config Override

Adjust search thresholds and result limits for testing.

### Search Parameters

**minMatch** (default: 0.88)
- Range: 0.0-1.0
- Minimum score threshold to include in results
- Lower = more results (more false positives)
- Higher = fewer results (might miss matches)
- Example: 0.70 for fuzzy exploration

**limit** (default: 10)
- Range: 1-100
- Maximum number of results to return
- Higher = more candidates but slower
- Example: 50 for comprehensive testing

### Use Cases

- **Recall testing**: Lower minMatch to 0.70 and increase limit to 50
- **Precision testing**: Raise minMatch to 0.95 for high-confidence only
- **Performance testing**: Vary limit to measure response time impact
- **Coverage testing**: Low threshold + high limit to find edge cases

## POST Search - Full Config Override

Comprehensive example showing all three config sections and query parameters.

### Complete Request Structure

```json
{
  "query": {
    "name": "...",              // Required: Entity name
    "addresses": [...],         // Optional: Address list
    "govIds": [...],            // Optional: Government IDs
    "dateOfBirth": "...",       // Optional: DOB (YYYY-MM-DD)
    "source": "OFAC_SDN",       // Optional: Filter by source
    "type": "PERSON"            // Optional: Filter by type
  },
  "config": {
    "similarity": {             // Optional: String matching params
      "jaroWinklerBoostThreshold": 0.75,
      "jaroWinklerPrefixSize": 5,
      "phoneticFilteringDisabled": false,
      "lengthDifferenceCutoffFactor": 3.0,
      "lengthDifferencePenaltyWeight": 0.20,
      "differentLetterPenaltyWeight": 0.10,
      "unmatchedIndexTokenWeight": 1.0,
      "exactMatchFavoritism": 0.10,
      "keepStopwords": false,
      "logStopwordDebugging": false
    },
    "scoring": {                // Optional: Component weights
      "nameWeight": 80.0,
      "addressWeight": 100.0,
      "criticalIdWeight": 200.0,
      "supportingInfoWeight": 60.0,
      "nameEnabled": true,
      "altNamesEnabled": true,
      "governmentIdEnabled": true,
      "cryptoEnabled": true,
      "contactEnabled": true,
      "addressEnabled": true,
      "dateEnabled": true
    },
    "search": {                 // Optional: Search params
      "minMatch": 0.85,
      "limit": 25
    }
  },
  "trace": true                 // Optional: Enable trace (default: true)
}
```

### Partial Overrides

**You only need to specify fields you want to override!**

- Omit entire sections (similarity, scoring, search) to use defaults
- Omit individual fields within sections to use default for that field
- null values are treated as "use default"

**Example - Override just one parameter:**
```json
{
  "query": {"name": "Test"},
  "config": {
    "search": {"minMatch": 0.95}
  }
}
```

### Admin/Testing Workflow

1. **Baseline**: Run with defaults (no config)
2. **Tune Similarity**: Adjust Jaro-Winkler params
3. **Tune Scoring**: Modify weights and toggles
4. **Set Threshold**: Adjust minMatch and limit
5. **Compare**: Review trace metadata to see applied values
6. **Iterate**: Repeat until desired behavior achieved

### Response

All config values are included in `debug.metadata` for verification:
- `config.similarity.*` - Applied similarity params
- `config.scoring.*` - Applied scoring weights/toggles
- `config.search.*` - Applied search params

response.name: Success with Full Config

item.name: Batch Screening
item.description:
## Batch Screening

Screen multiple entities simultaneously with efficient parallel processing.

### Endpoints

- **POST /v2/search/batch** - Synchronous batch screening (up to 1000 items)
- **POST /v2/search/batch/async** - Asynchronous processing for large batches

### Request Format

```json
{
  "items": [
    {"id": "req-1", "name": "John Smith"},
    {"id": "req-2", "name": "Acme Corp", "type": "BUSINESS", "source": "OFAC_SDN"}
  ],
  "minMatch": 0.85,
  "limit": 10,
  "trace": false
}
```

### Parameters

| Field | Type | Required | Description |
|-------|------|----------|-------------|
| `items` | array | ‚úÖ Yes | 1-1000 entities to screen |
| `items[].id` | string | ‚úÖ Yes | Your unique ID for this entity |
| `items[].name` | string | ‚úÖ Yes | Entity name to screen |
| `items[].type` | string | ‚ùå No | Filter: PERSON, BUSINESS, VESSEL, AIRCRAFT |
| `items[].source` | string | ‚ùå No | Filter: OFAC_SDN, US_CSL, EU_CSL, UK_CSL |
| `minMatch` | float | ‚ùå No | Score threshold (default: 0.85) |
| `limit` | int | ‚ùå No | Max results per item (default: 10) |
| `trace` | boolean | ‚ùå No | Enable detailed breakdowns (default: false) |

### Response Structure

```json
{
  "results": [
    {
      "itemId": "req-1",
      "name": "John Smith",
      "matches": [
        {
          "entityId": "12345",
          "name": "JOHN SMITH",
          "type": "PERSON",
          "source": "OFAC_SDN",
          "score": 0.98,
          "breakdown": null  // present when trace=true
        }
      ],
      "matchCount": 1,
      "trace": null  // present when trace=true
    }
  ],
  "statistics": {
    "totalItems": 1,
    "itemsWithMatches": 1,
    "itemsWithoutMatches": 0,
    "totalMatches": 1,
    "processingTimeMs": 45
  }
}
```

### Performance

| Batch Size | Avg Response Time | Recommended Use |
|------------|------------------|----------------|
| 1-10 items | < 100ms | Real-time checks |
| 11-100 items | < 500ms | Transaction monitoring |
| 101-500 items | 1-3s | Periodic screening |
| 501-1000 items | 3-8s | Batch processing |
| 1000+ items | Use async | Large bulk imports |

### Best Practices

‚úÖ **Use meaningful IDs**: Include your system IDs for easy correlation
‚úÖ **Batch related items**: Group by transaction, user session, or business process
‚úÖ **Handle partial failures**: Check `status` field for each item
‚úÖ **Enable trace sparingly**: Only for debugging (increases response time)
‚úÖ **Use async for 1000+ items**: Better for large batches and reduces timeouts

### Common Use Cases

**1. Transaction Batch Screening**
```json
{
  "items": [
    {"id": "txn-001", "name": "Sender Name"},
    {"id": "txn-001-recipient", "name": "Recipient Name"}
  ],
  "minMatch": 0.90
}
```

**2. Customer Onboarding Batch**
```json
{
  "items": [
    {"id": "cust-100", "name": "Primary Account Holder"},
    {"id": "cust-100-auth-1", "name": "Authorized User 1"},
    {"id": "cust-100-auth-2", "name": "Authorized User 2"}
  ],
  "minMatch": 0.85
}
```

**3. Vendor Screening with Filters**
```json
{
  "items": [
    {"id": "vendor-1", "name": "Supplier Co", "type": "BUSINESS"},
    {"id": "vendor-2", "name": "Logistics LLC", "type": "BUSINESS"}
  ],
  "minMatch": 0.85,
  "limit": 5
}
```

**4. Debug with Trace**
```json
{
  "items": [{"id": "test-1", "name": "Test Name"}],
  "trace": true,
  "minMatch": 0.70
}
```

### Error Handling

**400 Bad Request**
- Empty items array
- More than 1000 items
- Missing required fields (id, name)
- Invalid parameter values

**429 Too Many Requests**
- Rate limit exceeded
- Solution: Implement exponential backoff

**503 Service Unavailable**
- Service temporarily down
- Solution: Retry with delay or use async endpoint

### Sync vs Async

**Use Sync (`/v2/search/batch`)** when:
- Batch size < 1000 items
- Need immediate results
- Real-time transaction processing

**Use Async (`/v2/search/batch/async`)** when:
- Batch size > 1000 items
- Can wait for results
- Background job processing
- Want to avoid timeouts

request.description: Screen multiple entities in a single request (max 1000 items)
Batch screen with source and type filters

response.name: Filtered Batch Results

request.description: Batch screening with trace enabled to see detailed scoring breakdowns per match

response.name: Batch Response with Trace

request.description: Example large batch request (modify items array as needed, max 1000)
Submit batch for async processing (for very large batches)
Get batch screening configuration and limits

item.name: Data Management
item.description:
## Data Management & Refresh

Download and refresh sanctions list data from authoritative sources.

### Endpoints

- **POST /v2/data/download** - Download latest data from OFAC, EU, UK sources
- **POST /v2/data/refresh** - Refresh in-memory index with downloaded data

### Data Sources

| Source | Authority | Update Frequency | Entity Count |
|--------|-----------|------------------|-------------|
| **OFAC SDN** | US Treasury | Daily | ~12,500 |
| **US CSL** | US Govt Agencies | Weekly | ~8,000 |
| **EU CSL** | European Union | Daily | ~5,000 |
| **UK CSL** | UK OFSI | Daily | ~3,000 |

### Workflow

```
1. POST /v2/data/download  ‚Üí  Fetch latest data
2. POST /v2/data/refresh   ‚Üí  Reload into memory
3. GET /v2/listinfo        ‚Üí  Verify new counts
```

### Use Cases

‚úÖ **Scheduled Updates**: Automate daily data refresh via cron/scheduler
‚úÖ **Manual Refresh**: Update data after major sanctions announcements
‚úÖ **Version Control**: Track data versions and update history
‚úÖ **Compliance**: Maintain up-to-date sanctions screening data

### Best Practices

**Scheduling**:
- Download daily at off-peak hours (e.g., 2 AM UTC)
- Refresh immediately after successful download
- Monitor for download failures and retry

**Monitoring**:
- Check entity counts after refresh (`/v2/listinfo`)
- Alert if counts drop unexpectedly (data corruption)
- Log download timestamps for audit trails

**Zero Downtime**:
- Refresh operation is atomic (old data serves until new data ready)
- No service interruption during refresh
- Rollback available if new data has issues

### Response Codes

| Code | Meaning | Action |
|------|---------|--------|
| 200 | Success | Data updated |
| 202 | Accepted | Async operation started |
| 409 | Conflict | Refresh already in progress |
| 503 | Unavailable | Source unreachable, retry later |

### Performance

- **Download Time**: 30-60 seconds (depends on source availability)
- **Refresh Time**: 5-10 seconds (in-memory reload)
- **Impact**: Zero downtime, no request failures

### Security

- May require authentication/authorization in production
- Restrict access to admin/ops roles only
- Log all data management operations
- Validate data integrity after download

request.description: Trigger manual refresh of sanctions data from all sources
Get current status of data downloads

item.name: Nemesis Testing
item.description:
## Nemesis - Automated Parity Testing

Trigger and monitor automated testing that compares Java vs Go implementations (and optionally OFAC-API commercial service).

### What is Nemesis?

Nemesis is an **adversarial testing system** that:
- Generates dynamic test queries from real OFAC data (configurable: 1-1000 queries per run)
- Compares Java vs Go scoring for divergences
- Optionally includes OFAC-API (commercial gold standard) for 3-way comparison
- Uses AI to identify patterns and root causes
- Tracks cumulative entity coverage over time
- Generates GitHub issues for divergences found
- **(New!)** Automatically creates PRs with fixes via repair pipeline

### Endpoints

```
POST /v2/nemesis/trigger    - Start a Nemesis run
GET  /v2/nemesis/status/:id - Check job status
GET  /v2/nemesis/reports    - List recent reports
GET  /v2/nemesis/reports/:file - Download specific report
```

### Comparison Modes

**2-Way (Java vs Go)**:
```json
{
  "queries": 100,
  "includeOfacApi": false,
  "async": true
}
```

**3-Way (Java vs Go vs OFAC-API)**:
```json
{
  "queries": 100,
  "includeOfacApi": true,
  "async": true
}
```
*Requires `OFAC_API_KEY` environment variable*

### Response Structure

**Trigger Response**:
```json
{
  "jobId": "nemesis-20260111-143052",
  "status": "running",
  "statusUrl": "/v2/nemesis/status/nemesis-20260111-143052",
  "reportPath": null,
  "message": "Nemesis run started asynchronously"
}
```

**Status Response**:
```json
{
  "jobId": "nemesis-20260111-143052",
  "status": "completed",
  "queries": 100,
  "startTime": "2026-01-11T14:30:52",
  "endTime": "2026-01-11T14:31:35",
  "executionTimeSeconds": 43,
  "reportPath": "/data/reports/nemesis-20260111.json"
}
```

### Report Contents

Generated JSON reports include:
- **Divergences**: Score differences, wrong top matches, missing results
- **AI Analysis**: Pattern identification and root cause hypotheses
- **Coverage Metrics**: % of OFAC entities tested (cumulative)
- **Trace Data**: Score breakdowns for debugging (limited to samples)
- **Test Queries**: Sample queries used in the run
- **Repair Results**: PR URLs and fix status (if repair pipeline enabled)

### Use Cases

‚úÖ **Pre-Deployment Testing**: Run before releasing Java changes
‚úÖ **Regression Detection**: Catch scoring regressions early
‚úÖ **Parity Verification**: Ensure Java matches Go behavior
‚úÖ **Commercial Validation**: Compare against OFAC-API gold standard
‚úÖ **Continuous Monitoring**: Schedule daily runs via cron
‚úÖ **Automated Fixes**: Enable repair pipeline to auto-create PRs

### Workflow

**1. Trigger Run**
```
POST /v2/nemesis/trigger
{ "queries": 100, "includeOfacApi": false, "async": true }

‚Üí Returns jobId
```

**2. Monitor Progress**
```
GET /v2/nemesis/status/{jobId}

‚Üí Poll until status = "completed"
```

**3. Review Results**
```
GET /v2/nemesis/reports

‚Üí Download latest report
```

**4. Investigate Divergences**
- Review AI-identified patterns
- Check score breakdowns in trace data
- Prioritize by severity (critical ‚Üí moderate ‚Üí minor)

**5. Auto-Repair (Optional)**
- If `REPAIR_PIPELINE_ENABLED=true` on server
- PRs automatically created for fixable issues
- GitHub issue includes PR links

### Configuration (Server-Side)

```bash
# Basic configuration
WATCHMAN_JAVA_API_URL=https://watchman-java.fly.dev
WATCHMAN_GO_API_URL=https://watchman-go.fly.dev
COMPARE_IMPLEMENTATIONS=true

# 3-way comparison
COMPARE_EXTERNAL=true
EXTERNAL_PROVIDER=ofac-api
OFAC_API_KEY=your_api_key_here

# GitHub integration
GITHUB_TOKEN=your_github_token
GITHUB_REPO=BraidFI-AI/watchman-java

# Repair pipeline (auto-fix)
REPAIR_PIPELINE_ENABLED=true
```

### Performance

| Queries | 2-Way Time | 3-Way Time | Report Size |
|---------|-----------|-----------|-------------|
| 50 | ~20 sec | ~35 sec | ~2-5 MB |
| 100 | ~35 sec | ~60 sec | ~5-10 MB |
| 500 | ~3 min | ~5 min | ~25-50 MB |

*Note: Reports were previously 2.1GB due to full trace storage. Now limited to essential data and samples.*

### Divergence Types

| Type | Severity | Description |
|------|----------|-------------|
| `top_result_differs` | Critical | Different top match (compliance risk) |
| `score_difference` | Critical/Moderate | Same entity, different scores |
| `java_extra_result` | Moderate | Java over-matching |
| `go_extra_result` | Moderate | Java missing results |
| `result_order_differs` | Minor | Different ranking order |

### Best Practices

**Testing Frequency**:
- Run on every PR/deployment (CI/CD integration)
- Schedule daily runs in production
- Run 3-way comparison weekly for commercial validation

**Interpreting Results**:
- **0 divergences**: ‚úÖ Perfect parity
- **1-5 divergences**: ‚ö†Ô∏è Minor differences, investigate
- **10+ divergences**: üî¥ Systematic issue, block deployment

**Using AI Analysis**:
- Review AI-identified patterns first (saves time)
- Prioritize by priority (P0 > P1 > P2 > P3)
- Check if issue affects multiple queries (pattern vs edge case)

**Repair Pipeline**:
- Start disabled (`REPAIR_PIPELINE_ENABLED=false`)
- Enable after validating report quality
- Review auto-generated PRs before merging
- Keep crons disabled initially, enable after confidence

### Troubleshooting

**Job stuck in "running"**:
- Check server logs for errors
- API may be unreachable (Java/Go/OFAC-API)
- Timeout may have occurred

**3-way comparison fails**:
- Verify `OFAC_API_KEY` is set on server
- Check OFAC-API quota/rate limits
- Fall back to 2-way comparison

**Large report files (>100MB)**:
- Fixed in latest version (trace data limited)
- Older reports may still be large
- Download reports compress well (gzip recommended)

### GitHub Integration

When divergences are found:
1. **Issue Created**: Summary of all divergences with severity breakdown
2. **AI Analysis**: Patterns and recommendations included
3. **PR Links**: If repair pipeline enabled, links to auto-generated PRs
4. **Sample Divergences**: Top 10 examples with details

### Security

- Nemesis endpoints should be restricted to internal/admin access
- OFAC-API key is sensitive - store securely
- GitHub token needs repo write access for PRs
- Reports may contain entity names - handle per data privacy policies

request.description: Trigger a Nemesis parity testing run (Java vs Go baseline). Returns immediately with job ID.
Trigger a Nemesis run and wait for completion. Use for small query counts.
Trigger 3-way comparison: Java vs Go vs OFAC-API commercial service. Requires OFAC_API_KEY environment variable on server.
Check the status of a Nemesis job. Replace job ID with actual job ID from trigger response.
